details.title: Assessment of repairable-system reliability using proportional intensity models: a review

kwd: US Army M1A2 Arams Main Battle Tank

authors.affiliation: Global Concepts Inc., Little Rock, AR, USA

p: Shwu-Tzy Jiang received a Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering from the University of Oklahoma. Dr. Jiang is currently a consultant with Global Concepts, Inc., and is primarily participating in several projects in the energy industry. Her main research interests include reliability engineering, and maintainability technology in a repairable system. She was a finalist for the Best Student Paper Award, Quality, Statistics, and Reliability Section, INFORMS, 2004. She is a reviewer for IIE Transactions, and Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering. She is a member of IIE, and INFORMS..

authors.name: Shwu-Tzy Jiang

p: Thomas L. Landers joined the faculty at the University of Oklahoma in 1998 as Morris R. Pitman professor and director of the School of Industrial Engineering. He is currently dean and AT&T chair in the college of engineering at the University of Oklahoma, and has served as director for Oklahoma Center for Aircraft and Systems/Support Infrastructure, Oklahoma Transportation Center, and Center for Engineering Logistics and Distribution. His professional experience includes positions as consultant with Ernst and Young, development engineer with Texas Instruments, plant manager in the alternative energy field, and as reliability and maintainability engineer for the F-16 Systems Program Office at Wright-Patterson AFB. Dr. Landers has over 80 publications to his credit.

Teri Reed Rhoads is associate dean for engineering education in the College of Engineering and assistant professor in the School of Industrial Engineering at the University of Oklahoma. Dr. Rhoads teaches engineering statistics and quality engineering courses. Her research interests are diverse in that she studies effective means of learning in the engineering classroom, including the incorporation of web-based learning in statistics. She is interested in not only the cognitive domain of learning, but also the affective domain and how to assess each. In addition, she researches recruitment and retention issues.

details.abstract: This paper provides an overview of methods, and surveys the literature on engineering applications of proportional intensity (PI) models with explanatory variables (covariates), for repairable systems reliability assessment. The semi-parametric PI method relaxes the assumption of an underlying distribution, and is potentially useful in engineering practice, where the underlying information for a failure process is usually not available. PI semi-parametric models initially proposed for clinical studies in medical applications include PWP (Prentice, Williams, and Peterson), AG (Andersen, and Gill), and WLW (Wei, Lin, and Weissfeld). Abundant funding received in medical research has advanced PI models to become well developed, and widely referenced in the biostatistics field. This paper reviews both the available methods for repairable-system reliability assessment, and the published engineering application case studies. An engineering application example that applies PI model to a maintainability process used in US Army M1A2 Arams Main Battle Tank is presented.

references.title: Regression models and lifetables (with discussion)

context.text: Cox [1] proposed a proportional hazard (PH) rate function regression model for a non-repairable system.
The Cox [1] PH model deals with a single event, whereas many researchers have expanded the PH model capability to handle recurrent events.

references.text: D. R. Cox, "Regression models and lifetables (with discussion)", Journal of the Royal Statistical Society. Series B, vol. 34, pp. 187-220, 1972.

references.title: Some results for repairable systems with general repair

context.text: The value of \$\lambda\$ varies from 0 to 1 depending on the repair types, such as minimal repair (\$\lambda=0\$, as-bad-as-old), imperfect repair \$(0< \lambda< 1)\$, and replacement (\$\lambda=1\$, as-good-as-new) (Usher et al. [2], Kijima [3], Kijima et al. [4]).

references.text: M. Kijima, "Some results for repairable systems with general repair", Journal of Applied Probability, vol. 26, pp. 89-102, 1989.

Imperfect
maintenance

context.text: Pham & Wang [5] provide a thorough survey of literature on imperfect maintenance.

links.abstract: This paper studies a multi-objective maintenance optimization embedded within the imperfect preventive maintenance (PM) for one single-unit system subject to the dependent competing risks of degradation wear and random shocks. We consider two kinds of random shocks in the system: 1) fatal shocks that will cause the system to fail immediately, and 2) nonfatal shocks that will increase the system degradation level by a certain cumulative shock amount. Also, an improvement factor in the form of qua...

references.text: H. Pham, H. Wang, "Imperfect maintenance", European Journal of Operation Research, vol. 94, pp. 425-438, 1996.

references.title:
On the regression analysis of multivariate failure time
data

context.text: Prentice, Williams, and Peterson (PWP) [6] proposed a semi-parametric approach to model recurrent event data using two methods: PWP-GT (gap time), and PWP-TT (total time).
Prentice, Williams, and Peterson (PWP) [6] proposed a method that generalizes the proportional hazards (PH) model.

references.text: R. L. Prentice, B. J. Williams, A. V. Peterson, "On the regression analysis of multivariate failure time data", Biometrika, vol. 68, no. 2, pp. 373-379, 1981.

references.title:
Cox's regression model for counting processes: a large sample
study

context.text: Several researchers subsequently proposed alternate modeling methods, and applied them to clinical practices in medical studies, including Andersen & Gill (AG) [7], and Wei, Lin, & Weissfeld (WLW) [8].
Andersen & Gill [7] developed the AG method as an extension of the Cox PH model to accommodate recurring events in a counting process.

references.text: P. K. Andersen, R. D. Gill, "Cox's regression model for counting processes: a large sample study", The Annals of Statistics, vol. 10, no. 4, pp. 1100-1120, 1982.

references.title:
Regression analysis of multivariate incomplete failure time
data by modeling marginal distributions

context.text: Several researchers subsequently proposed alternate modeling methods, and applied them to clinical practices in medical studies, including Andersen & Gill (AG) [7], and Wei, Lin, & Weissfeld (WLW) [8].
WLW [8] in a bladder cancer study examined treatment effects by using the PWP, and WLW models.

references.text: L. J. Wei, D. Y. Lin, L. Weissfeld, "Regression analysis of multivariate incomplete failure time data by modeling marginal distributions", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 84, no. 408, pp. 1065-1073, Dec. 1989.

references.title:
Survival analysis for recurrent data: An application to
childhood infectious diseases

context.text: Kelly & Lim [9] defined the major components (i.e. risk sets, and risk intervals) that form a PI model, and classified the PI models into family types based on risk sets, and risk intervals.
However, the risk interval of the gap time begins from the end of last event (Kelly & Lim [9]).
Risk interval formulations (Kelly and Lim [9]). (a) Gap time; (b) total time; (c) counting process.
Risk interval formulations (Kelly and Lim [9]). (a) Gap time; (b) total time; (c) counting process.
Table I summarizes the proportional intensity modeling methods, categorized by the Kelly & Lim [9] taxonomy on the basis of risk set versus risk interval.
Kelly & Lim [9] addressed three ways to deal with misspecification problems: conditional, marginal, and random effects.

Kelly & Lim [9] applied the conditional, and marginal approaches to childhood infectious disease cases, and concluded that applying the marginal method (robust variance) is not effective to resolve misspecification problems if any dependence exists.

references.text: P. J. Kelly, L. L.-Y. Lim, "Survival analysis for recurrent data: An application to childhood infectious diseases", Statistics in Medicine, vol. 19, pp. 13-33, 2000.

references.title: Discussion of paper by Wei and Glidden

context.text: Lipschutz & Snapinn [10] suggested guidelines in choosing the appropriate models.
In a commentary on the Wei & Glidden paper, Lipschutz & Snapinn [10] stressed the two concepts of “event times,” and “risk sets” as crucial to choosing the appropriate model.

references.text: K. H. Lipschutz, S. M. Snapinn, "Discussion of paper by Wei and Glidden", Statistics in Medicine, vol. 16, pp. 841-851, 1997.

references.title:
An overview of statistical methods for multiple failure
time data in clinical trials

context.text: Wei & Glidden [11] gave an overview of statistical methods for multiple failure time data in clinical trials, and urged caution required in using semi-parametric PI models when there are dependence structures among recurrent events.
Wei & Glidden [11] reviewed the Cox-based methods designed to model recurrent data, and summarized the strengths & weaknesses for each method.

references.text: L. J. Wei, D. V. Glidden, "An overview of statistical methods for multiple failure time data in clinical trials", Statistics in Medicine, vol. 16, pp. 833-839, 1997.

references.title: The robust inference for the Cox proportional hazards model

context.text: Some researchers proposed a few methods in dealing with this situation to enhance the model accuracy, such as Lin & Wei [12].
Other researchers have worked on the robust variance model, such as Lin & Wei [12], and Therneau & Hamilton [28], to name a few.

references.text: D. Y. L. Dy, L. J. Wei, "The robust inference for the Cox proportional hazards model", Journal of the American Statistical Association: Theory and Methods, vol. 84, no. 408, pp. 1074-1078, Dec. 1989.

references.title:
Robustness evaluation of a semi-parametric proportional
intensity model

context.text: [13], and Landers et al. [14] examined the PWP-GT model, and characterized the more favorable engineering application ranges based on sample sizes, and shape parameter values.
[13] summarized the case of a single constant covariate in implementing the parametric Lawless method, where the underlying baseline hazard function follows the power-law form.
[13] conducted robustness studies of the PWP model over cases and parameter ranges typical of engineering applications.

references.text: W. M. Qureshi, T. L. Landers, E. E. Gbur, "Robustness evaluation of a semi-parametric proportional intensity model", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 44, pp. 103-109, 1994.

references.title:
Semi-parametric PWP model robustness for log-linear increasing
rates of occurrence of failures

context.text: [14] examined the PWP-GT model, and characterized the more favorable engineering application ranges based on sample sizes, and shape parameter values.
[14] investigated a log-linear baseline hazard function.
[14] applied PI models to a real world example of a maintainability (restoration) process (log-linear with two explanatory covariates) for the US Army M1A2 Abrams Main Battle Tank.

[14] examined the robustness of the PWP method for the case of an underlying failure process following the NHPP with log-linear proportional intensity function \$\lambda(t)=\exp(\theta\times t)\exp({\bf z}{\mmb \beta})\$, where \$\theta\$ is the shape parameter, \${\bf z}\$ is the covariate variable, and \${\mmb \beta}\$ is the regression coefficient.

references.text: T. L. Landers, S. T. Jiang, J. R. Peek, "Semi-parametric PWP model robustness for log-linear increasing rates of occurrence of failures", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 73, pp. 145-153, 2001.

references.title:
Semi-parametric
proportional intensity models robustness for right-censored recurrent failure
data

context.text: [15]–[17] investigated the robustness of these PI models for a set of special engineering applications, including right-censoring severity, life cycles with substantial overhaul (dormancy) intervals, and multiple failure types (major and minor).
[15] extended the robustness characterization research to an important case of the right-censorship, and examined PWP, AG, and WLW models.

references.text: S. Jiang, T. L. Landers, T. R. Rhoads, "Semi-parametric proportional intensity models robustness for right-censored recurrent failure data", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 90, no. 1, pp. 91-98, 2005.

references.title:
Proportional intensity models
robustness with overhaul intervals

context.text: Jiang et al. [15]–[16][17] investigated the robustness of these PI models for a set of special engineering applications, including right-censoring severity, life cycles with substantial overhaul (dormancy) intervals, and multiple failure types (major and minor).

[16] considered repair times due to major overhaul in a recurrent failure process, examined the overhaul durations that could affect the model performance if neglected, and concluded that the PWP model performs well for relative overhaul durations less than 1/2 of the immediately preceding interval between failures.

references.text: S. Jiang, T. L. Landers, T. R. Rhoads, "Proportional intensity models robustness with overhaul intervals", Quality and Reliability Engineering International.

links.abstract: The Prentice, Williams, Peterson (PWP) semiparametric model for the failure processes of repairable systems involves regression on explanatory variables across strata defined by the failure-event count. A heuristic method is developed for assessing the robustness of the PWP model, where the true underlying process is nonhomogeneous Poisson with power-law intensity function. The PWP model performed well for large samples and increasing rates of occurrence of failures and poorly for small samples ...

references.text: T. L. Landers, H. E. Soroudi, "Robustness of a semi-parametric proportional intensity model", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 40, no. 2, pp. 161-164, Jun. 1991.

references.title: Assessment of a Proportional Intensity Model for Repairable-System Reliability

context.text: Soroudi [19], Landers & Soroudi [20], Qureshi [21], and Qureshi et al. [13] summarized the case of a single constant covariate in implementing the parametric Lawless method, where the underlying baseline hazard function follows the power-law form.

The special case of a single constant covariate adapted by Qureshi [21] from Lawless [23] yields the score vector \$U_{0}\$, \$U_{1}\$, and information matrix with elements \$G_{00}\$, \$G_{01}\$, \$G_{10}\$, \$G_{11}\$ as follows.
The model Qureshi [21] employed in a robustness study of the PWP model can be classified as \$({\rm risk}\ {\rm interval}, {\rm risk}\ {\rm set}) = ({\rm gap}\ {\rm time}, {\rm common})\$.

references.text: W. M. Qureshi, Assessment of a Proportional Intensity Model for Repairable-System Reliability, Dec. 1991, The University of Arkansas.

references.title: Robustness of Semi-Parametric Proportional Intensity Model for the Case of a Log-Linear Nonhomogeneous Poisson Process

context.text: Likewise, Vithala [22] and Landers et al. [14] investigated a log-linear baseline hazard function.

In the special case of single constant covariate, the score vector \$(U_{0},U_{1})^{\prime}\$, and information matrix with elements \$G_{00}\$, \$G_{01}\$, \$G_{10}\$, \$G_{11}\$, is as follows (Vithala [22], adapted from Lawless [23]):
Utilizing the score vector and information matrix, \$\mathhat{\beta}_{0}\$, \$\mathhat{\beta}_{1}\$ are calculated, for the scale parameter estimates \$\mathhat{\mu}_{0}\$, \$\mathhat{\mu}_{1}\$ in the two strata defined by the single covariate \$\mathhat{\mu}_{0}=\mathhat{\beta}_{0}\$, \$\mathhat{\mu}_{1}=\mathhat{\beta}_{0}+\mathhat{\beta }_{1}\$.
Likewise, Vithala [22] may be classified as \$({\rm risk}\ {\rm interval}, {\rm risk}\ {\rm set}) = ({\rm gap}\ {\rm time}, {\rm event}{-}{\rm specific})\$.

references.text: S. Vithala, Robustness of Semi-Parametric Proportional Intensity Model for the Case of a Log-Linear Nonhomogeneous Poisson Process, Dec. 1994, The University of Arkansas.

references.title: The Statistical Analysis of Series of Events

context.text:
Likewise, given the baseline intensity function specified as log-linear, the parametric proportional intensity function is (Cox and Lewis [24])
Let \$z_{0}=1\$; then \$\exp(\mu)=\exp(\beta_{0})\$, yielding exponential link function \$\exp(\mathtilde{\bf z}\mathtilde{\mmb\beta})=\exp(z_{0}\beta_{0}+z_{1}\beta_{1}+\ldots z_{k}\beta_{k})\$. \$(\theta,\mu)\$ is the shape parameter, and the scale parameter.

references.title:
Proportional hazards modeling of time-dependent covariates
using linear regression: A case study

context.text: Kumar & Westberg [33] studied a class of earth-moving equipment, known as load-haul-dump (LHD) machines.

links.abstract: In the proportional hazards model, the effect of a covariate is assumed to be time-invariant. In this paper a graphical method based on a linear regression model (LRM) is used to test whether this assumption is realistic. The variation in the effect of a covariate is plotted against time. The slope of this plot indicates the nature of the influence of a covariate over time. A covariate is time-dependent if a drastic change in the slope of the plot is found and the time-point, at which this drast...

references.text: D. Kumar, U. Westberg, "Proportional hazards modeling of time-dependent covariates using linear regression: A case study", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 45, no. 3, pp. 386-392, 1996.
